editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Atey Brutus Affar Corin Thrafi Debon Locrine Guendaline Cambert Strumbo Trom Dorothy Ateyas Humber Hubba Astrilo Segar Captain Albanact Thrasimachus All Estrild Oliuer Wiliam Margerie Souldier Page Madan Sabren

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.head:
THE Lamentable Tragedy of Locrine the eldest son of King Brutus discoursing the wars of the Britaines, and Hunnes, with their discomfiture:
The Britaines victory with their Accidents, and the death of Albanact. No&H2; less pleasant than profitable.
Newly set forth, overseen and corrected, By W. S.
LONDON Printed by Thomas Creede. 1595.
The lamentable Tragedy of Locrine, the eldest son of King Brutus, discoursing the wars of the Britaines and Hunnes, with their discomfiture, the Britaines victory with their accidents, and the death of Albanact.

div2.head: The first Act. Scene 1.
div2.stage: Enter Atey with thunder and lightning all in black, with a burning torch in one hand, and a bloodie swoord in the other hand, and presently let there come foorth a Lion running after a Beare or any other beast, then come foorth an Archer who&H61; must kill the Lion in a dumbe show, and then depart. Remaine Atey.

sp.speaker: Atey.
sp.l: A Mighty Lion ruler of the woods,
Of wondrous strength and great proportion,
With hideous noise scarring the trembling trees,
With yelling clamours shaking all the earth,
Traversed the groves, and chased the wandering beasts.
Long did he range amid the shady trees,
And drove the silly beasts before his face,
When suddenly from out a thorny bush,
A dreadful Archer with his bow ybent,
Wounded the Lion with a dismal shaft,
So&H3; he him stroke that&H3; it drew forth the blood,
And filled his furious heart with fretting ire,
But all in&H4; vain he threateneth teeth and paws,
And sparkleth fire from forth his flaming eyes,
For&H3; the sharpe shaft gave him a mortal wound,
So&H3; valiant Brute the terror of the world,
Whose only looks did scar his enemies,
The Archer death brought to&H4; his latest end.
O what may long abide above this ground,
In&H4; state of bliss and healthful happiness.

div2.head: The first Act. Scene. 2.
div2.stage: Enter Brutus carried in a chaire, Locrine, Camber, Albanact, Corineius, Guendelin, Assaracus, Debon, Thrasimachus.

sp.speaker: Burtus
sp.l: Most loyal Lords and faithful followers
That&H61; have with me unworthy General,
Passed the greedy gulf of Ocean,
Leaving the confines of fair Italy,
Behold our&Htp; Brutus draweth nigh his end,
And I must leave you though against my will&H0;,
My sinews shrunk, my numbed senses fail,
A chilling cold possesseth all my bones,
Black ugly death with visage pale and wan,
Presents himself before my dazzled eyes,
And with his dart prepared is to&H9; strike,
These arms my Lords, these never daunted arms,
That&H61; oft have quelled the courage of my foes,
And eke dismayed my neighbours arrogancy,
Now yield to&H4; death, overlaid with crooked age,
Devoid of strength and of their proper force,
Even as the lusty cedar worn with years,
That&H61; far abroad her&H2; dainty odour throws,
Mongst all the daughters of proud Lebanon,
This heart my Lords, this near appalled heart,
That&H61; was a terror to&H4; the bordering lands,
A doleful scourge unto my neighbour Kings,
Now by&H4; the weapons of unpartial death,
Is clove asunder and bereft of life,
As when the sacred oak with thunderbolts,
Sent from the fiery circuit of the heavens,
Sliding along the aires celestial vaults,
Is rent and cloven to&H4; the very roots.
In&H4; vain therefore I strangle with this foe,
Then welcome death, since God will&H1; have it so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Affar
sp.l: Alas my Lord, we&Htp; sorrow at your case,
And grieve to&H9; see your person vexed thus,
But whatsoever the fates determined have,
It lieth not in&H4; us&Htp; to&H9; disannul,
And he that&H61; would annihilate his mind,
Soaring with Icarus too near the Sun,
May catch a fall with young Bellerophon,
For&H3; when the fatal sisters have decreed
To&H9; separate us&Htp; from this earthly mould,
No&H2; mortal force can countermand their minds:
Then worthy Lord since there is no&H2; way but one,
Cease your laments, and leave your grievous moan.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Your highness knows how many victories
How many trophies I erected have,
Triumphantly in&H4; every place we&Htp; came
The Grecian Monarch warlike Pandrassus,
And all the crew of the Molossians,
Goffarius the arm strong King of Gaules,
And all the borders of great Aquitane,
Have felt the force of our&Htp; victorious arms,
And to&H4; their cost beheld our&Htp; chivalry,
Wherever Ancora handmaid of the Sun,
Wherever the Sun-bright guardant of the day,
Wherever the joyful day with cheerful light,
Wherever the light illuminates the word,
The Troyans glory flies with golden wings,
Wings that&H61; do soar beyond fell envious flight,
The fame of Brutus and his followers,
Pierceth the skies, and with the skies the throne
Of mighty Jove Commander of the world,
Then worthy Brutus,leave these sad laments,
Comfort yourself with this your great renown,
And fear not death though he seem terrible.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Nay Corinus you mistake my mind
In&H4; construing wrong the cause of my complaints,
I feared to&H9; yield myself to&H4; fatal death,
Cod knows it was the least of all my thought,
A greater care torments my very bones,
And makes me tremble at the thought of it,
And in&H4; you Lordings doth the substance lie.

sp.speaker: Thrafi
sp.l: Most noble Lord, if ought your loyal
Accomplish may, to&H9; ease your lingering grief, peers
I in&H4; the name of all protest to&H4; you,
That&H3; we&Htp; will&H1; boldly enterprise the same,
Were it to&H9; enter to&H4; black Tartarus,
Where triple Cerberus with his venomous throat,
Scareth the ghosts with high resounding noise,
We&Htp; will&H1; either rent the bowels of the earth,
Searching the entrails of the brutish earth,
Or with his Ixions overdaring soon,
Be bound in&H4; chains of ever during steel.

sp.speaker: Bru
sp.l: Then hearken to&H4; your sovereign's latest words,
In&H4; which&H61; I will&H1; unto you all unfold,
Our&Hrp; royal mind and resolute intent,
When golden Hebe daughter to&H4; great Jove,
Covered my manly cheeks with youthful down,
The unhappy slaughter of my luckless sire,
Drove me and old Assarachus mine came,
As exiles from the bounds of Italy,
So&H3; that&H3; perforce we&Hrp; were constrained to&H9; fly
To&H4; Graecians Monarch noble Pandrassus,
There I alone did undertake your cause,
There I restored your antique liberty,
Though Grecia frowned, and all Mollossia stormed,
Though brave Antigonus with martial band,
In&H4; pitched field encountered me and mine,
Though Pandrassus and his contributories,
With all the
out of their confederates,
Sought to&H9; deface our&Htp; glorious memory,
And wipe the name of Troians from the earth,
Him did I captivate with this mine arm,
And by&H4; compulsion forced him to&H9; agree
To&H4; certain articles which&H61; there we&Hrp; did propound,
From Graecia through the boisterous Hellespont,
We&Htp; came unto the fields of Lestrigon,
Whereas our&Hrp; brother Corineius was,
Which&H61; when we&Hrp; passed the Cicillian gulf,
And so&H52; transfretting the Illician sea,
Arrived on&H4; the coasts of Aquitane,
Where with an army of his barbarous Gaules
Goffarius and his brother Gathelus
Encountering with our&Hrp; host, sustained the foil,
And for&H4; your sakes my Turnus there I lost,
Turnus that&H61; slew six hundreth men at arms
All in&H4; an hour, with his sharpe battle-axe,
From thence upon&H4; the strands of Albion
To&H4; Corus haven happily we&Hrp; came,
And quelled the giants, come of Albions race,
With Gogmagog son to&H4; Samotheus,
The cursed Captain of that&H62; damned crew,
And in&H4; that&H62; Isle at length I placed you.
Now let me see if my laborious toils,
If all my care, if all my grievous wounds,
If all my diligence were well employed.

sp.speaker: Corin.
sp.l: When first I followed thee and thine brave king)
I hazarded my life and dearest blood,
To&H9; purchase favour at your princely hands,
And for&H4; the same in&H4; dangerous attempts
In&H4; sundry conflicts and in&H4; divers broils,
I showed the courage of my manly mind,
For&H4; this I combated with Gathelus,
The brother to&H4; Goffarius of Gaule,
For&H4; this I fought with furious Gogmagog,
A savage captain of a savage crew,
And for&H4; these deeds brave Cornwale I received,
A grateful gift given by&H4; a gracious King,
And for&H4; this gift, this life and dearest blood,
Will&H1; Corineus spend for&H4; Brutus good.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.l: And what my friend brave prince hath vowed to&H4; you,
The same will&H1; Debon do unto his end.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Then loyal peers since you are all agreed,
And resolute to&H9; follow Brutus hosts,
Favour my sons, favour these Orphans Lords,
And shield them from the dangers of their foes,
Locrine the column of my family,
And only pillar of my weakened age.
Locrine draw near, draw near unto thy sire,
And take thy latest blessings at his hands,
And or thou art the eldest of my sons,
Be thou a captain to&H4; thy brethren,
And imitate thy aged fathers steps,
Which&H61; will&H1; conduct thee to&H4; true honour's gate,
For&H3; if thou follow sacred virtue's lore,
Thou shalt be crowned with a laurel branch,
And wear a wreath of sempiternall fame,
Sorted amongst the glorious happy ones.

sp.speaker: Locrine.
sp.l: If Locrine do not follow your advice,
And bear himself in&H4; all things like&H4; a prince
That&H61; seeks to&H9; amplify the great renown
Left unto him for&H4; an inheritage
By&H4; those that&H61; were his ancestors,
Let me be flung into the Ocean,
And swallowed in&H4; the bowels of the earth.
Or let the ruddy lightning of great Jove,
Descend upon&H4; this my devolted head.
sp.stage: Brutus taking Guendoline by&H4; the hand.
sp.l: But for&H3; I see you all to&H9; be in&H4; doubt,
who&H61; shall be matched with our&Hrp; royal son,
Locrine receive this present at my hand,
A gift more rich than are the wealthy mines
Found in&H4; the bowels of America,
Thou shalt be spoused to&H4; fair Guendoline,
Love her&H6;, and take her&H6;, for&H3; she is thine own,
If so&H52; thy uncle and herself do please.

sp.speaker: Corin.
sp.l: And herein how your highness honours me
It cannot be in&H4; my speech expressed,
For&H3; careful parents glory not so&H51; much
At their honour and promotion,
As for&H3; to&H9; see the issue of their blood
Seated in&H4; honour and prosperity.

sp.speaker: Guend.
sp.l: And far be it from my maiden's thoughts
To&H9; contradict her&H2; aged fathers will&H0;,
Therefore since he to&H4; whom I must obey
Hath given me now unto your royal self,
I will&H1; not stand aloof from off the lure,
Like&H4; crafty dames that&H61; most of all deny
That&H62;, which&H61; they most desire to&H9; possess.
sp.stage: Brutus turning to Locrine. Locrine kneeling.
sp.l: Then now my soon thy part is on&H4; the stage,
For&H3; thou must bear the person of a King.
sp.stage: Puts the Crowne on his head.
sp.l: Locrine stand up&H5;, and wear the regal Crown,
And think upon&H4; the state of Majesty,
That&H3; thou with honour well mayst wear the crown,
And if thou tenderest these my latest words,
As thou requirest my soul to&H9; be at rest,
As thou desirest thine own security,
Cherish and love thy new betrothed wife.

sp.speaker: Locrin.
sp.l: No&H2; longer let me well enjoy the crown,
Than I do peerless Guendoline.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: The glory of mine age.
And darling of thy mother Iuoger,
Take thou the South for&H4; thy dominion,
From thee there shall proceed a royal race,
That&H61; shall maintain the honour of this land,
That&H61; sway the regal sceptre with their hands.
And Albanact thy fathers only joy,
Youngest in&H4; years, but not the youngest in&H4; mind,
A perfect pattern of all chivalry,
Take thou the North for&H4; thy dominion,
A country full of hills and ragged rocks,
Replenished with fierce untamed beasts,
As correspondent to&H4; thy martial thoughts,
Live long my sons with endless happiness,
And bear firm concordance amongst yourselves,
Obey the counsels of these fathers grave,
That&H3; you may better bear out violence,
But suddenly through weakness of my age,
And the defect of youthful puissance,
My malady increaseth more and more,
And cruel death hasteneth his quickened pace,
To&H9; dispossess me of my earthly shape,
Mine eyes wax dim, overcast with clouds of age,
The pangs of death compass my crazed bones,
Thus to&H4; you all my blessings I bequeath,
And with my blessings, this my fleeting soul.
My glass is run, and all my miseries
Do end with life: death closeth up&H5; mine eyes,
My soul is haste flies to&H4; the Elysian fields.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Accursed stars, damned and accursed stars,
To&H9; abbreviate my noble fathers life,
Hardhearted gods, and too envious fates,
Thus to&H9; cut off my fathers fatal thread,
Brutus that&H61; was a glory to&H4; us&Htp; all,
Brutus that&H61; was a terror to&H4; his foes,
Alas too soon by&H4; Demogorgon's knife,
The martial Brutus is beret of life.
No&H2; sad complaints may move just Lacus.

sp.speaker: Corin.
sp.l: No&H2; dreadful threats can fear judge Rhodomanth
Wert thou as strong as mighty Hercules,
That&H61; tamed the hugy monsters of the world,
Playedest thou as sweet, on&H4; the sweet sounding lute,
As did the spouse of fair Euridies,
That&H61; did enchant the waters with his noise,
And made stones, birds, and beasts, to&H9; lead a dance,
Constrained the hilly trees to&H9; follow him,
Thou couldst not move the judge of Crebus,
Nor move compassion in&H4; grim Plutos heart,
For&H3; fatal Mors expecteth all the world,
And every man must tread the way of death,
Brave Tantalus the valiant Pelops sire,
Guest to&H4; the gods, suffered untimely death,
And old Fleithonus husband to&H4; the morn,
And eke grim Minos whom just Iupiter
Deigned to&H9; admit unto his sacrifice,
The thundering trumpets of bloodthirsty Mars.
The fearful rage of fell Tisiphone.
The boisterous waves of humid Ocean,
Are instruments and tools of dismal death.
Then noble cousin cease to&H9; mourn his chance,
Whose age and years were signs that&H3; he should die.
It resteth now that&H3; we&Hrp; inter his bones,
That&H61; was a terror to&H4; his enemies.
Take up&H5; the coarse, and princes hold him dead,
Who&H61; while he lived, upheld the Troyan state.
Sound drums and trumpets, march to&H4; Troinouant,
There to&H9; provide our&Hrp; chieftain's funeral.

div2.head: The first Act. Scene 3.
div2.stage: Enter Strumbo aboue in a gowne, with inke and paper in his hand, saying;

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Either the four elements, the seven planets and all the particular stars of the pole Antastick, are adversative against me, or else I was begotten and borne in&H4; the wane of the Moon, when everything is saith Lactantius in&H4; his fourth book of Constultations doth say, goeth a ward. Aye masters Aye, you may laugh, but I must weep; you may joy, but I must sorrow; shedding salt tears from the watery fountains of my most dainty fair eyes, along my comely and smooth cheeks, in&H4; as great plenty as the water runneth from the bucking-tubs, or red wine out of the hogs heads: for&H3; trust me gentlemen and my very good friends, and so&H52; forth: the little god, nay the desperate god Cuprit, with one of his vengible birdbolts, hath shot me unto the heel: so&H3; not only, but also, o fine phrase, I burn, I burn, and I burn a, in&H4; love, in&H4; love, and in&H4; love a, ah Strumbo what has thou seen, not Dina with the Ass Tom? Yea with these eyes thou hast seen her&H6;, and therefore pull hem out: for&H3; they will&H1; work thy bale. Ah Strumbo hast thou heard, not the voice of the Nightingale, but a voice sweeter than hers, yea with these ears hast thou heard them, and therefore cut them off, for&H3; they have caused they sorrow. Nay Strumbo kill thyself, drown thyself, hang thyself, starve thyself. O but then I shall leave my sweet heart. O my heart, Now pate for&H4; thy master, I will&H1; endite an eloquent love-pistle to&H4; her&H6;, and then she hearing the grand verbosity of my scripture, will&H1; love me presently. Let him write a litle and then read. My pen is naught, gentlemen lend me a knife, I think the more haste the worst speed. Then write againe, and after read. So&H3; it is mistress Dorothie, and the sole essence of my soul, that&H3; the little sparkles of affection kindled in&H4; me towards your sweet self, hath now increased to&H4; a great flame, and will&H1; ere it be long consume my poor heart, except you with the pleasant water of your secret fountain, quench the furious heat of the same. Alas I am a gentleman of good fame, and name, majestic, in&H4; apparel comely, in&H4; gate portly. Let not therefore your gentle heart be so&H51; hard as to&H9; despise a proper tall young man of a handsome life, and by&H4; despising him, not only, but also to&H9; kill him. Thus expecting time and tide, I bid you farewell Your servant, Signior Strumbo.
O wit, O pate, O memory, O hand, O ink, O paper. Well now I will&H1; send it away. Trompart, Trompart, what a villain is this? Why sirrah, come when your master calls you, Trompart.

sp.l: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Thou knowest my pretty boy what a good master I have been to&H4; thee ever since I took thee into my service.

sp.speaker: Trom.
sp.l: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: And how I have cherished thee always, as if you had been the fruit of my loins, flesh of my flesh, and bone of my bone?

sp.speaker: Trom.
sp.l: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Then show thyself herein a trusty servant, and carry this letter to&H4; mistress Dorothie, and tell her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Nay masters you shall see a marriage by&H5; and by&H5;. But here she comes. Now must I frame my amorous passions.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Signior Strumbo,well met, I received your letters by&H4; your man here, who&H61; told me a pitiful story of your anguish, and so&H3; understanding your passions were so&H51; great, I came hither speedily.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: O my sweet and pigsney, the fecundity of my ingeny is not so&H51; great, that&H3; may declare unto you the sorrowful sobs and broken sleeps, that&H61; I suffered for&H4; your sake; and therefore I desire you to&H9; receive me into your familiarity.

l.hi: As mine eye to&H4; my nose,
And my flesh unto my skin.

sp.speaker: Doro.
Strum.
sp.p: Alas mistress Dorothie this is my luck, that&H3; when I most would, I cannot be understood: so&H3; that&H3; my great learning is an inconvenience unto me. But to&H9; speak in&H4; plain terms, I love you mistress Dorothie,if you like&H1; to&H9; accept me into your familiarity.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: If this be all I am content.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Sayst thou so&H52; sweet wench, let me lick thy toes. Farewell mistress. If any of you be in&H4; love, provide ye a cap-case full of new coined words, and then shall you soon have the succado de labres,and something else.

div2.head: The first Act. Scene 4.
div2.stage: Enter Locrine, Guendoline, Camber, Albanact, Corineus, Assaracus, Debon, Thrasimachus.

sp.speaker: Locrine.
sp.l: Uncle and princes of brave Britany,
Since that&H3; our&Hrp; noble father is entombed,
As best beseemed so&H51; brave a prince as he,
If so&H52; you please, this day my love and I,
Within the temple of Concordia,
Will&H1; solemnise our&Hrp; royal marriage.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Right noble Lord, your subjects every one,
Must needs obey your highness at command,
Especially in&H4; such a cause as this,
That&H61; much concerns your highness great content.

sp.speaker: Locr.
sp.l: Then frolic lordings to&H4; fair Concords walls,
Where we&Htp; will&H1; pass the day in&H4; knightly sports,
The night in&H4; dancing and in&H4; figured masks,
And offer to&H4; God Risus all our&Htp; sports.

div2.head: The 2. Act. Scene 1.

sp.speaker: Ate.
sp.l: When Perseus married fair Andromeda,
The only daughter of king Cepheus,
He thought he had established well his Crown,
And that&H3; his kingdom should for&H4; aye endure.
But lo proud Phineus with a band of men,
Contrived of sun-burnt Aethiopians:
By&H4; force of arms the bride he took from him,
And turned their joy into a flood of tears.
So&H52; fares it with young Locrine and his love,
He thinks this marriage tendeth to&H4; his weal,
But this foul day, this foul accursed day,
Is the beginning of his miseries.
Behold where Humber and his Scithians
Approacheth nigh with all his warlike train,
I need not I, the sequel shall declare,
What tragic chances fall out in&H4; this war.

div2.head: The 2. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Humber, Hubba, Estrilo, Segar, and their souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: At length the snail doth clime the highest tops,
Ascending up&H5; the stately castle walls,
At length the water with continual drops,
Doth penetrate the hardest marble stone,
At length we&Htp; are arrived in&H4; Albion,
Nor could the barbarous Dacian sovereign,
Nor yet the ruler of brave Belgia
Stay us&Htp; from cutting over to&H4; this I will&H1;,
Whereas I hear a troop of Phrigians
Under the conduct of Postumis son,
Have pitched up&H5; lordly pavilions,
And hope to&H9; prosper in&H4; this lovely I will:
But I will&H1; frustrate all their foolish hope,
And teach them that&H3; the Scithian Emperor
Leads fortune tied in&H4; a chain of gold,
Constraining her&H6; to&H9; yield unto his will&H0;,
And grace him with their regal diadem:
Which&H61; I will&H1; have maugre their treble hosts,
And all the power their petty kings can make.

sp.speaker: Hubba.
sp.l: If she that&H61; rules fair Rhanis golden gate
Grant us&Htp; the honour of the victory,
As hitherto she always favoured us&Htp;,
Right noble father, we&Htp; will&H1; rule the land,
Enthronized in&H4; seats of Topaz stones,
That&H3; Locrine and his brethren all may know,
None must be king but Humber and his son.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Courage my son, fortune shall favour us&Htp;,
And yield to&H4; us&Htp; the coronet of bay,
That&H61; decketh none but noble conquerors:
But what saith Estrild to&H4; these regions?
How liketh she the temperature thereof,
Are they not pleasant in&H4; her&H2; gracious eyes?

sp.speaker: Astr.
sp.l: The plains my Lord garnished with Floras wealth
And overspread with party coloured flowers,
Do yield sweet contentation to&H4; my mind,
The airy hills enclosed with shady groves,
The groves replenished with sweet chirping birds,
The birds resounding heavenly melody,
Are equal to&H4; the groves of Thessaly,
Where Phaebus with the learned Ladies nine,
Delight themselves with music harmony,
And from the moisture of the mountain tops,
The silent springs dance down with murmuring, streams,
And water all the ground with crystal waves,
The gentle blasts of Eurus modest wind,
Moving the pittering leaves of Siluanes woods,
Do equal it with Tempes paradise,
And thus comforted all to&H4; one effect,
Do make me think these are the happy Isles,
Most fortunate, if Humber may them win.

sp.speaker: Hubba
sp.l: Madam, where resolution leads the way,
And courage follows with emboldened pace,
Fortune can never use her&H2; tyranny,
For&H3; valiantness is like&H4; unto a rock
That&H61; standeth in&H4; the waves of Ocean,
Which&H61; though the billows beat on&H4; every side,
And Borras fell with his tempestuous storms,
Bloweth upon&H4; it with a hideous clamour,
Yet it remaineth still unmovable.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Kingly resolved thou glory of thy sire,
But worthy Segar what uncouth novelties
Bringst thou unto our&Hrp; royal majesty?

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: My Lord, the youngest of all Brutus sons,
Stout Albanct, with millions of men,
Approacheth nigh, and meaneth ere the morn,
To&H9; try your force by&H4; dint of fatal sword.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Tut let him come with millions of hostess,
He shall find entertainment good enough,
Yea fit for&H4; those that&H61; are our&Hrp; enemies:
For&H3; we&Htp; will&H1; receive them at the lances' points,
And massacre their bodies with our&Htp; blades:
Yea though they were in&H4; number infinite,
More than the mighty Babilonian queen,
Semiramis the ruler of the West,
Brought gainst the Emperor of the Scithians,
Yet would we&Htp; not start back one foot from them:
That&H3; they might know we&Htp; are invincible.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Now by&H4; great Jove the supreme king of heaven,
And the immortal gods that&H61; live therein,
When as the morning shows his cheerful face,
And Lucifer mounted upon&H4; his steed,
Brings in&H5; the chariot of the golden sun,
I will meet young Albanact in&H4; the open field,
And crack my lance upon&H4; his burgeon,
To&H9; try the valour of his boyish strength:
There will&H1; I show such ruthful spectacles
And cause so&H51; great effusion of blood,
That&H3; all his boys shall wonder at my strength:
As when the warlike queen of Amazon,
Penthisilea armed with her&H2; lance,
Girt with a corslet of bright shining steel,
Cooped up&H5; the faint-heart Graecians in&H4; the camp.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Spoke like&H4; a warlike knight my noble son,
Nay like&H4; a prince that&H61; seeks his fathers joy,
Therefore tomorrow ere fair Titan shine,
And bashful Eos messenger of light:
Expels the liquid sleep from out men's eyes,
Thou shalt conduct the right wing of the host,
The left wing shall be under Segars charge,
The rearward shall be under me myself,
And lovely Estrild fair and gracious,
If fortune favour me in&H4; mine attempts,
Thou shalt be queen of lovely Albion,
Fortune shall favour me in&H4; mine attempts,
And make the Queen of lovely Albion.
Come let us&Htp; in&H5; and muster up&H5; our&Hrp; train,
And furnish up&H5; our&Hrp; lusty soldiers,
That&H3; they may be a bulwark to&H4; our&Hrp; state,
And bring our&Hrp; wished joys to&H4; perfect end.

div2.head: The 2. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Strumbo, Dorothie, Trompart cobling shooes and singing.

sp.speaker: Trum
sp.l: We&Htp; Cobblers lead a merry life,

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan:

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: Void of all envy and of strife:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan diddle dan.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Our&Htp; ease is great, us&Htp; labour small:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: And yet us&Htp; gains be much withal:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan diddle dan.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: With this art&H0; so&H51; fine and fair:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: No&H2; occupation may compare

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan diddle dan:

sp.speaker: Strum
sp.l: For&H4; merry pastime and joyful glee:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Most happy men we&Htp; Cobblers be:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan diddle dan.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: The can stands full of nappy ale,

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan: dan: dan: dan:

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: In&H4; us&Htp; shop still withouten fail:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan diddle dan.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This is us&Htp; meat, this is us&Htp; food:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan: dan: dan: dan:

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: This brings us&Htp; to&H4; a merry mood:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan didle dan.

sp.speaker: Strum
sp.l: This makes us&Htp; work for&H4; company:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To&H9; pull the tankards cheerfully:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan didle dan.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Drink to&H4; thy husband Dorothie,

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why then my Strumbo there is to&H4; thee:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan didle dan:

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: Drink thou the rest Trumpart main:

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan, dan, dan, dan.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: When that&H62; is gone we&Htp; will&H1; fill it again,

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Dan didle dan.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The poorest state is farthest from annoy,
How merrily he sitteth on&H4; his stool:
But when he sees that&H3; needs he must be pressed,
He will&H1; turn his note and sing another tune,
Ho, by&H4; your leave master Cobbler:

sp.speaker: Stru.
sp.p: You are welcome gentleman, what will&H1; you any old shoes or buskins, or will&H1; you have your shoes clouted, I will&H1; do them as well as any Cobbler in&H4; Cathues whatsoever?

sp.l: O master Cobbler you are far deceived in&H4; me, for&H3; do not you see this? I come not to&H9; buy any shoes, but to&H9; buy yourself; come sir you must be a soldier in&H4; the kings cause.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Why but hear you sir, has your king any commission to&H9; take any man against his will&H0;. I promise you I can scant believe it, or did he give you commission?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O sir, ye need not care for&H4; that&H62;, I need no&H2; commission: hold here, I command you in&H4; the name of us&Htp; king Albanact, to&H9; appear tomorrow in&H4; the townhouse of Gathnes.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: King Nactabell, I cry God mercy, what have we&Htp; to&H9; do with him, or he with us&Htp;? but you sir master capotaile, draw your pasteboard, or else I promise you, I will give you a canuasado with a bastinano over your shoulders, and teach you to&H9; come hither with your implements.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I pray thee good fellow be content, I do the kings command.

sp.speaker: Strum
sp.l: Put me out of your book then.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: I may not.
No&H7; well, come sir will&H1; your stomach serve you, by&H4; gogs blue hood and halidom, I will&H1; have about with you.
How now, what noise, what sudden clamour is this?
How now, my captain and the cobbler so&H51; hard at it?
Sirs what is your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Nothing sir, but that&H3; he will&H1; not take press money.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Here good fellow take it at my command,
Unless you mean to&H9; be stretched.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Truly master gentleman, I lack no&H2; money, if you please I will&H1; resign it to&H4; one of these poor fellows.

sp.speaker: Thrafi
sp.l: No&H2; such matter,
Look you be at the common house tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: O wife I have spun a fair thread, if I had been quiet, I had not been pressed, and therefore well may I wayment; But come sirrah shut up&H5;, for&H3; we&Htp; must to&H4; the wars.

div2.head: The 4. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Albanact, Debon, Thrasimachus, and the Lords.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Brave cavaliers, princes of Albany,
Whose trenchant blades with our&Hrp; deceased sire,
Passing the frontiers of brave Graecia,
Were bathed in&H4; our&Hrp; enemies lukewarm blood,
Now is the time to&H9; manifest your wills,
Your haughty minds and resolutions,
Now opportunity is offered
To&H9; try your courage and your earnest zeal,
Which&H61; you always protest to&H4; Albanact,
For&H3; at this time, yea at this present time,
Stout fugitives come from the Scithians bounds
Have pestered every place with mutinies:
But trust me Lordings I will&H1; never cease
To&H9; persecute the rascal runagates,
Till all the rivers stained with their blood,
Shall fully show their fatal overthrow.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.l: So&H52; shall your highness merit great renown,
And imitate your aged fathers steps.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: But tell me cousin, camest thou through the plains?
And sawest thou there the faint heart fugitives
Mustering their weather-beaten soldiers,
What order keep they in&H4; their marshalling?

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: After we&Htp; past the groves of Caledone,
Where murmuring rivers slide with silent streams
We&Htp; did behold the straggling Scithians camp,
Replete with men, stored with munition;
There might we&Htp; see the valiant minded knights
Fetching carriers along the spacious plains,
Humber and Hubba armed in&H4; azure blue,
Mounted upon&H4; their coursers white as snow,
Went to&H9; behold the pleasant flowering fields;
Hector and Troialus, Priamus lovely sons,
Chasing the Graecians over Simoeis,
Were not to&H9; be compared to&H4; these two knights.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Well hast thou painted out in&H4; eloquence
The portraiture of Humber and his son;
As fortunate as was Policrates,
Yet should they not escape us&Htp; conquering swords,
Or boast of ought but of our&Hrp; clemency.
sp.stage: Enter Strumbo and Trompart, crying often;
sp.l: Wild fire and pitch, wild fire and pitch, etc.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: What sirs what mean you by&H4; these clamours made,
Those outcries raised in&H4; our&Hrp; stately court?

sp.speaker: Strum
sp.l: Wild fire and pitch, wild fire and pitch.

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.l: Villains I say, tell us&Htp; the cause hereof?

sp.speaker: Strum
sp.l: Wild fire and pitch, etc.

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.l: Tell me you villains, why you make this noise,
Or with my lance I will&H1; prick your bowels out.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: Where are your houses, where is your dwelling place?

sp.speaker: Strum
sp.p: Place, Ha, ha, ha, laugh, a month and a day at him; place, I cry God mercy, why do you think that&H3; such poor honest men as we&Htp; be, hold our&Htp; habitacles in&H4; kings palaces: Ha? ha, ha. But because you seem to&H9; be an abominable chieftain, I will&H1; tell you our&Htp; state.
sp.l: From the top to&H4; the toe,
From the head to&H4; the shoe;
From the beginning to&H4; the ending,
From the building to&H4; the burning.
sp.p: This honest fellow and I had our&Htp; mansion cottage in&H4; the suburbs of this city, hard by&H5; the temple of Mercury. And by&H4; the common soldiers of the Shitens, the Scithians; what do you call them? with all the suburbs were burnt to&H4; the ground, and the ashes are left there, for&H4; the country wives to&H9; wash bucks withal. And that&H62; which&H61; grieves me most, my loving wife, O cruel strife; the wicked flames did roast.
sp.l: And therefore captain crust,
We&Htp; will&H1; continually cry,
Except you seek a remedy
Our&Htp; houses to&H9; re-edify
Which&H61; now are burnt to&H4; dust.
; Wild fire and pitch, wild fire and pitch.

sp.speaker: Alba
sp.l: Well we&Htp; must remedy these outrages,
And throw revenge upon&H4; their hateful heads,
And you good fellows for&H4; your houses burnt,
We&Hrp; will&H1; remunerate you store of gold,
And build your houses by&H4; our&Hrp; palace gate.

sp.speaker: Strumbo
Alba
sp.l: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Strum.
Alba.
sp.l: It grieves me lordings that&H3; my subjects' goods
Should thus be spoiled by&H4; the Scithians,
Who&H61; as you see with light-foot foragers
Depopulate the places where they come,
But cursed Humber thou shalt rue the day
That&H61; ere thou camest unto Cathuesia.

div2.head: The 2. Act. Scene 5.
div2.stage: Enter Humber, Hubba, Segar, Trussier, and their souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Hubba, go take a coronet of our&Hrp; horse
As many lancers, and light armed knights
As may suffice for&H4; such an enterprise,
And place them in&H4; the grove of Caledon,
With these, when as the skirmish doth increase
Retire thou from the shelters of the wood,
And set upon&H4; the weakened Troians backs,
For&H3; policy joined with chivalry
Can never be put back from victory.

div2.stage: Exit. Albanact enter and say, clownes with him.

sp.l: Thou base borne Hunne, how durst thou be so&H51; bold
As once to&H9; menace warlike Albanact?
The great commander of these regions,
But thou shalt buy thy rashness with thy death,
And rue too late thy over bold attempts,
For&H3; with this sword this instrument of death,
That&H61; hath been drenched in&H4; my foe-men's blood,
I will separate thy body from thy head,
And set that&H62; coward blood of thine abroach.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: Nay with this staff great Strumbos instrument,
I will crack thy cocks come paltry Scithian.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nor wreak I of thy threats thou princox boy,
Nor do I fear thy foolish insolency,
And but thou better use thy bragging blade,
Than thou dost rule thy overflowing tongue,
Superbious Brittaine, thou shalt know too soon
The force of Humber and his Scithians.
Let them fight.

div2.stage: Humber and his souldiers runne in.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: O horrible, terrible.

div2.head: The sixt Act.
div2.stage: Sound the alarme. Enter Humber and his souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: How bravely this young Brittain Albanact
Darteth abroad the thunderbolts of war,
Beating down millions with his furious mood;
And in&H4; his glory triumphs over all,
Moving the massy squadrants of the ground;
Heap hills on&H4; hills, to&H9; scale the starry sky,
When Briareus armed with an hundreth hands
Flung forth an hundreth mountains at great Jove,
And when the monstrous giant Monichus
Hurled mount Olimpus at great Mars his targe,
And shot huge caedars at Mineruas shield;
How doth he overlook with haughty front
My fleeting hostess, and lifts his lofty face
Against us&Htp; all that&H61; now do fear his force,
Like&H3; as we&Htp; see the wrathful sea from far
In&H4; a great mountain heaped with hideous noise
With thousand billows beat against the ships
And toss them in&H4; the waves like&H4; tennis balls.

sp.speaker: Humb.
sp.l: Ay me, I fear my Hubba is surprised.

sp.speaker: Alba
sp.l: Follow me soldiers, follow Albanact;
Pursue the Scithians flying through the field:
Let none of them escape with victory:
That&H3; they may know the Brittains force is more
Than all the power of the trembling Hunnes.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Forward brave soldiers, forward keep the chase
He that&H61; takes captive Humber or his son,
Shall be rewarded with a crown of gold.

div2.stage: Sound alarme, then let them fight,Humber giue backe, Hubba enter at their backs, and kill Debon, let Strumbo fall downe, Albanact run in, and afterwards enter wounded.

sp.speaker: Alba
sp.l: Injurious fortune hast thou crossed me thus?
Thus in&H4; the morning of my victories,
Thus in&H4; the prime of my felicity
To&H9; cut me off by&H4; such hard overthrow;
Hadst thou no&H2; time thy rancour to&H9; declare,
But in&H4; the spring of all my dignities?
Hadst thou no&H2; place to&H9; spit thy venom out
But on&H4; the person of young Albanact?
I that&H61; ere while did scare mine enemies,
And drove them almost to&H4; a shameful flight,
I that&H61; ere while full lion-like did fare
Amongst the dangers of the thick thronged pikes,
Must now depart most lamentably slain
By&H4; Humbers treacheries and fortunes spites:
Cursed be their charms, damned be her&H2; cursed charms
That&H61; doth delude the wayward hearts of men,
Of men that&H61; trust unto her&H2; fickle wheel,
Which&H61; never leaveth turning upside down.
O gods, O heavens, allot me but the place
Where I may find her&H2; hateful mansion,
I will pass the Alps to&H4; watery Merae,
Where fiery Phoebus in&H4; his chariot
The wheels whereof are decked with Emeralds,
Cast such a heat, yea such a scorching heat,
And spoileth Flora of her&H2; chequered grass,
I will overrun the mountain Cancusus,
Where fell Chimera in&H4; her&H2; triple shape
Rolleth hot flames from out her&H2; monstrous paunch,
Scaring the beasts with issue of her&H2; gorge,
I will pass the frozen Zone where icy flakes
Stopping the passage of the fleeting ships
Do he, like&H4; mountains in&H4; the congealed sea,
Where if I find that&H62; hateful house of hers,
I will pull the fickle wheel from out her&H2; hands,
And tie herself in&H4; everlasting bands:
But all in&H4; vain I breath these threatenings,
The day is lost, the Hunnes are conquerors,
Deoon is slain, my men are done to&H4; death,
The currents swift, swim violently with blood
And last, O that&H3; this last night so&H51; long last,
Myself with wounds past all recovery,
Must leave my crown for&H4; Humber to&H9; possess.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Lord have mercy upon&H4; us&Htp;; masters I think this is a holy day, every man lies sleeping in&H4; the fields, but God knows full sore against their wills.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Fly noble Albanact and save thyself,
The Scithians follow with great celerity,
And there is no&H2; way but fight, or speedy death,
Fly noble Albanact and save thyself.

sp.speaker: Alba
sp.l: Nay let them fly that&H61; fear to&H9; die the death
That&H61; tremble at the name of fatal mors,
Never shall proud Humber boast or brag himself
That&H3; he hath put young Albanact to&H4; flight,
And least he should triumph at my decay,
This sword shall reave his master of his life,
That&H61; oft hath saved his master's doubtful life:
But o my brethren if you care for&H4; me,
Revenge my death upon&H4; his traitorous head.
Et vos queis domus ect nigrantis regia ditis,

l.foreign: Qui regitis rigido stigios moder amine lucos:
Nox caeci rgina poli furialis Erinnis
Dique de aeque omnes Albanum tolliteregem
Nunc me fata vocat, hoc condam pectore ferrum.

sp.l: Thrust himself through.
O what hath he done, his nose bleeds? but o I smell a fox,
Look where my master lies, master, master.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: Let me alone I tell thee, for&H3; I am dead.

sp.speaker: Trom.
sp.l: Yet one, good, good, master.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: I will&H1; not speak, for&H3; I am dead I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Trom.
sp.l: And is my master dead?
O sticks and stones, brickbats and bones,
and is my master dead?
O you cockatrice and you bablatrices,
that&H61; in&H4; the woods dwell:
You briers and brambles, you cooks shops and shambles,
come howl and yell.
With howling and shrieking, with wailing and weeping.
come you to&H9; lament.
O Colliers of Croyden, and rustics of Royden,
and fishers of Kent.
For&H4; Strumbo the cobbler, the fine merry cobbler
of Cathnes town
At this same stour, at this very hour
lies dead on&H4; the ground.
O master, thieves, thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: Where be they? cox me
Tunny, bobekin let me be rising, be gone, we&Htp; shall be robbed by&H5; and by&H5;.

div1.head: The 3. Act.
div1.stage: Enter Humber, Hubba, Segar, Thrassier, Estrild, and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Thus from the dreadful shocks of furious
Mars Thundering alarms, and Rhamnusias drum
We&Htp; are retired with joyful victory,
The slaughtered Troians squeltering in&H4; their blood,
Infect the air with their carcasses,
And are a pray for&H4; every ravenous bird.

sp.speaker: Estrild
sp.l: So&H52; perish they that&H61; are our&Htp; enemies.
So&H52; perish they that&H61; love not Humbers weal.
And mighty Jove commander of the world,
Protect my love from all false treacheries.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Thanks lovely Estrild, solace to&H4; my soul.
But valiant Hubba for&H4; thy chivalry
Declared against the men of Albany,
Lo here a flowering garland wreathed of bay,
As a reward for&H4; thy forward mind.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This unexpected honour noble sir,
Will&H1; pick my courage unto braver deeds,
And cause me to&H9; attempt such hard exploits,
That&H3; all the world shall sound of Hubbaes name.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: And now brave soldiers for&H4; this good success,
Carouse whole cups of Amazonian wine,
Sweeter than Nectar or Ambrosia,
And cast away the clods of cursed care,
With goblets crowned with Semeleius gifts,
Now let us&Htp; march to&H4; Abis silver streams
That&H61; clearly glide along the Champane fields,
And moist the gray meads with humid drops.
Sound drums and trumpets, sound up&H5; cheerfully,
Sith we&Htp; return with joy and victory.

div2.head: The 3. Act. Scene 1.
div2.stage: Enter Ate as before. The dumb show. A Crocadile sitting on a riuers banke, and a little Snake stinging it. Then let both of them fall into the water.

sp.speaker: Ate.
sp.l: High on&H4; a bank by&H4; Nilus boisterous streams,
Fearfully sat the Aegiptian Crocodile,
Dreadfully grinding in&H4; her&H2; sharpe long teethe,
The broken bowels of a silly fish,
His back was armed against the din of spear,
With shields of brass that&H61; shined like&H4; burnished gold
And as he stretched forth his cruel paws,
A subtle Adder creeping closely near
Thrusting his forked sting into his claws,
Privily shed his poison through his bones
Which&H61; made him swell that&H3; there his bowels burst,
That&H61; did so&H51; much in&H4; his own greatness trust.
So&H3; Humber having conquered Albanact,
Doth yield his glory unto Locrines sword.
Mark what ensues and you may easily see,
That&H3; all our&Htp; life is but a Tragedy.

div2.head: The 2. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Locrine, Guendoline, Corineus, Affaracus, Thrasimachus, Camber.

sp.speaker: Locrine
sp.l: And is this true, is Albanactus slain?
Hath cursed Humber with his straggling host
With that&H62; his army made of mongrel curs,
Brought our&Hrp; redoubted brother to&H4; his end.
O that&H3; I had the Thracian Orpheus harp
For&H3; to&H9; awake out of the infernal shade
Those ugly devils of black Erebs,
That&H61; might torment the damned traitors soul:
O that&H3; I had Amphions instrument
To&H9; quicken with his vital notes and tunes
The flinty joints of every stony rock,
By&H4; which&H61; the Scithians might be punished,
For&H3; by&H4; the lightening of almighty Jove
The Hunne shall die, had he ten thousand lives:
And would to&H4; God he had ten thousand lives,
That&H3; I might with the arm-strong Hercules
Crop off so&H51; vile an Hidras hissing heads,
But say me cousin, for&H3; I long to&H9; hear
How Albanact came by&H4; untimely death?

sp.speaker: Thrafi.
sp.l: After the traitorous host of Scithians,
Entered the field with martial equipage
Young Albanact impatient of delay
Led forth his army gainst the straggling mates,
Whose multitude did daunt our&Htp; soldiers' minds,
Yet nothing could dismay the forward prince,
But with a courage most heroical
Like&H4; to&H4; a lion mongst a flock of lambs
Made havoc of the faint heart fugitives,
Hewing a passage through them with his sword,
Yea we&Htp; had almost given them the repulse
When suddenly from out the silent wood
Hubba with twenty thousand soldiers
Cowardly came upon&H4; our&Htp; weakened backs,
And murthered all with fatal massacre,
Amongst the which&H61; old Debon martial knight,
With many wounds was brought unto the death.
And Albanact oppressed with multitude
Whilst valiantly he felled his enemies
Yielded his life and honour to&H4; the dust,
He being dead, the soldiers fled amain,
And I alone escaped them by&H4; flight,
To&H9; bring you tidings of these accidents.

sp.speaker: Locr
sp.l: Not aged Priam King of stately Troy,
Grand Emperor of barbarous Asia,
When he beheld his noble minded sons
Slain traitorously by&H4; all the Mermidons,
Lamented more than I for&H4; Albanact.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: Not Hecaba the queen of Ilium
When she beheld the town of Pergamus,
Her&H2; palace burnt, with all devouring flames,
Her&H2; fifty sons and daughters fresh of hue,
Murthered by&H4; wicked Pirrhus bloody sword,
Shed such sad tears as I for&H4; Albanact.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The grief of Niobe fair Athens queen,
For&H3; her&H2; seven sons magnanimous in&H4; field,
For&H3; her&H2; seven daughters fairer than the fairest,
Is not to&H9; be compared with my laments.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: In&H4; vain you sorrow for&H4; the slaughtered prince,
In&H4; vain you sorrow for&H4; his overthrow,
He loves not most that&H61; doth lament the most,
But he that&H61; seeks to&H9; venge the injury.
Think you to&H9; quell the enemies warlike train,
With childish sobs and womanish laments?
Unsheathe your swords, unsheathe your conquering sword,
And seek revenge, the comfort for&H4; this sore,
In&H4; Cornwall where I hold my regiment
Even just ten thousand valiant men at arms
Hath Corineus ready at command:
All these and more, if need shall more require,
Hath Corrineus ready at command.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And in&H4; the fields of martial Cambria,
Close by&H4; the boisterous Iscans silver streams,
Where light-foot fairies skip from bank to&H4; bank,
Full twenty thousand brave courageous knights
Well exercised in&H4; feats of chivalry,
In&H4; manly manner most invincible,
Young Camber hath with gold and victual,
All these and more, if need shall more require,
I offer up&H5; to&H9; venge my brothers death.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Thanks loving uncle and good brother too,
For&H3; this revenge, or this sweet word revenge
Must ease and cease thy wrongful injuries,
And by&H4; the sword of bloody Mars I swear,
Never shall sweet quiet enter this my front,
Till I be venged on&H4; his traitorous head
That&H61; slew my noble brother Albanact.
Sound drums and trumpets, muster up&H5; the camp,
For&H3; we&Htp; will&H1; straight march to&H4; Albania.

div2.head: The 3. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Humber, Estrild, Hubba, Trussier, and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.l: Thus are we&Htp; come victorious conquerors
Unto the flowing currents silver streams
Which&H61; in&H4; memorial of our&Htp; victory,
Shall be agnominated by&H4; our&Hrp; name,
And talked of by&H4; our&Hrp; posterity:
For&H3; sure I hope before the golden sun
Posteth his horses to&H4; fair Thetis plains,
To&H9; see the waters turned into blood,
And change his bluish hue to&H4; rueful red,
By&H4; reason of the fatal massacre
Which&H61; shall be made upon&H4; the virent plains.
See how the traitor doth presage his harm,
See how he glories at his own decay,
See how he triumphs at his proper loss,
O fortune vild, unstable, fickle, frail.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.l: Methinks I see both armies in&H4; the field,
The broken lances clime the crystal skies,
Some headless lie, some breathless on&H4; the ground,
And every place is strewed with carcasses,
Behold the grass hath lost his pleasant green,
The sweetest sight that&H61; ever might be seen.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Aye traitorous Humber, thou shalt find it so&H52;,
Yea to&H4; thy cost thou shalt the same behold,
With anguish, sorrow, and with sad laments,
The grassy plains that&H61; now do please thine eyes,
Shall ere the night be coloured all with blood,
The shady groves which&H61; now enclose thy camp
And yield sweet savours to&H4; thy damned corps,
Shall ere the night figured all with blood,
The profound stream that&H61; passeth by&H4; thy tents,
And with his moisture serveth all thy camp,
Shall ere the night converted be to&H4; blood,
Yea with the blood of those thy straggling boys,
For&H3; now revenge shall ease my lingering grief,
And now revenge shall glut my longing soul.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Let come what will&H1;, I mean to&H9; bear it out,
And either live with glorious victory,
Or die with fame renowned for&H4; chivalry,
He is not worthy of the honey comb
That&H61; shuns the hives because the bees have stings,
That&H62; likes me best that&H61; is not got with ease,
Which&H61; thousand dangers do accompany,
For&H3; nothing can dismay our&Hrp; regal mind,
Which&H61; aims at nothing but a golden crown,
The only upshot of mine enterprises,
Were they enchanted in&H4; grim Plutos court,
And kept for&H4; treasure mongst his hellish crew,
I would either quell the triple Cerberus
And all the army of his hateful hags,
Or roll the stone with wretched Sisiphon.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.l: Right martial be thy thoughts my noble son,
And all thy words savour of chivalry,
But warlike Segar what strange accidents
Makes you to&H9; leave the warding of the camp.

sp.speaker: Segar.
sp.l: To&H4; arms my Lord, to&H4; honourable arms,
Take helm and targe in&H4; hand the Brittaines come,
With greater multitude than erst the Greeks
Brought to&H4; the ports of Phrigian Tenidos.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.l: But what saith Segar to&H4; these accidents?
What counsel gives he in&H4; extremities?

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: Why this my Lord experience teacheth us&Htp;,
That&H3; resolution is a sole help at need.
And this my Lord our&Htp; honour teacheth us&Htp;,
That&H3; we&Htp; be bold in&H4; every enterprise,
Then since there is no&H2; way but fight or die,
Be resolute my Lord for&H4; victory.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.l: And resolute Segar I mean to&H9; be,
Perhaps some blissful star will&H1; favour us&Htp;,
And comfort bring to&H4; our&Htp; perplexed state:
Come let us&Htp; in&H5; and fortify our&Htp; camp,
So&H52; to&H9; withstand their strong invasion.

div2.head: The 4. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Strumbo, Trumpart, Oliuer, and his sonne William following them.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Nay neighbour Oliuer, if you be so&H51; hot, come prepare yourself, you shall find two as stout fellows of us&Htp;, as any in&H4; all the North.

sp.speaker: Oliu.
sp.p: No&H7; by&H4; my dorth neighbour Strumbo, I see that&H3; you are a man of small zideration, that&H61; will&H1; seek to&H9; injure your old friends, one of your familiar guests, and therefore seeing your pinion is to&H9; deal withouten reason, I and my son William will&H1; take that&H62; course, that&H61; shall be farthest from reason, how say you, will&H1; you have my daughter or no&H7;?

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: A very hard question neighbour, but I will&H1; solve it as I may; what reason have you to&H9; demand it of me?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Marry sir, what reason had you when my sister was in&H4; the barn to&H9; rumble her&H6; upon&H4; the hay, and to&H9; fish her&H2; belly.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Mass thou sayst true, well, but would you have me marry her&H6; therefore? No&H7; I scorn her&H6;, and you, and you. Aye, I scorn you all.

sp.speaker: Oliu.
sp.l: You will&H1; not have her&H6; then?

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: No&H7; as I am a true gentleman.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Then will&H1; we&Htp; school you, ere you and we&Htp; part hence.

div2.stage: Enter Margerie and snatch the staffe out of her&H2; brothers hand, as he is fighting.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Aye you come in&H4; pudding time, or else I had dressed them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You master sauce-box, lobcock, coxcomb, you slopsauce, lickfingers, will&H1; you not hear?

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Who&H62; speak you too, me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Aye sir to&H4; you, Iohn lackhonesty, little wit, is it you that&H61; will&H1; have none of me?

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: No&H7; by&H4; my troth, mistress nicebice, how fine you can nickname me, I think you were brought up&H5; in&H4; the university of bridewell, you have your rhetoric so&H51; ready at your tounge's end, as if you were never well warned when your were young.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why then goodman cods-head, if you will&H1; have none of me, farewell.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: If you be so&H51; plain mistress drigle dragle, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay master Strumbo, ere you go from hence we&Htp; must have more words, you will&H1; have none of me?

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: O my head, my head, leave, leave, leave, I will&H1;, I will&H1;, I will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Upon&H4; that&H62; condition I let thee alone.

sp.speaker: Oliu.
sp.p: How now master Strumbo, hath my daughter taught you a new lesson?

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: Aye but hear you goodman Oliuer? it will&H1; not be for&H4; my ease to&H9; have my head broken every day, therefore remedy this and we&Htp; shall agree.

sp.speaker: Oliu.
sp.p: Well son well, for&H3; you are my son now, all shall be remedied, daughter be friends with him.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: You are a sweet nut; the devil crack you. Masters I think it be my luck, my first wife was a loving quiet wench, but this I think would weary the devil. I would she might be burnt as my other wife was. If not, I must run to&H4; the halter for&H4; help. O codpiece thou hast done thy master, this it is to&H9; be meddling with warm plackets.

div2.head: The 5. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Locrine, Camber, Corineus, Thrasimachus, Assarachus.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Now am I guarded with an host of men,
Whose haughty courage is invincible,
Now am I hemmed with troupes of soldiers,
Such as might force Bellona to&H9; retire,
And make her&H6; tremble at their puissance,
Now sit I like&H4; the mighty god of war,
When armed with his coat of Adamant,
Mounted his chariot drawn with mighty bulls,
He drove the Argiues over Xanthus streams.
Now cursed Humber doth thy end draw nigh,
Down goes the glory of his victories,
And all his fame, and all his high renown
Shall in&H4; a moment yield to&H4; Locrines sword,
Thy bragging banners crossed with argent streams,
The ornaments of thy pavilions
Shall all be captivated with this hand,
And thou thyself at Albanactus tomb
Shalt offered be in&H4; satisfaction
Of all the wrongs thou didst him when he lived.
But canst thou tell me brave Thrasimachus,
How far We&Htp; are distant from Humbers camp?

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.l: My Lord, within your foul accursed grove
That&H61; bears the tokens of our&Htp; overthrow,
This Humber hath entrenched his damned camp.
March on&H5; my Lord, because I long to&H9; see
The treacherous Seithians squeltering in&H4; their gore.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Sweet fortune favour Locrine with a smile,
That&H3; I may venge my noble brothers death,
And in&H4; the midst of stately Troinonant,
I will build a temple to&H4; thy deity
Of perfect marble and of Iacinthe stones,
That&H3; it shall pass the high Pyramids
Which&H61; with their top surmount the firmament.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The arm-strong offspring of the doubted knight,
Stout Hercules Alcmenas mighty son,
That&H61; tamed the monsters of the threefold world,
And rid the oppressed from the tyrants yokes,
Did never show such valiantness in&H4; fight,
As I will&H1; now for&H4; noble Albanact.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Full four score years hath Corineus lived,
Sometime in&H4; war, sometime in&H4; quiet peace,
And yet I feel myself to&H9; be as strong
As erst I was in&H4; summer of mine age,
Able to&H9; toss this great unwieldy club
Which&H61; hath been painted with my foemens brains,
And with this club i will break the strong array
Of Humber and his straggling soldiers,
Or loose my life amongst the thickest press,
And die with honour in&H4; my latest days,
Yet ere I die they all shall understand
What force lies in&H4; stout Corineus hand.

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.l: And if Thrasimachus detract the fight,
Either for&H4; weakness or for&H4; cowardice,
Let him not boast that&H3; Brutus was his eame,
Or that&H3; brave Corineus was his sire.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Then courage soldiers, first for&H4; your safety,
Next for&H4; your peace, last for&H4; your victory.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Sound the alarme. Enter Hubba and Segar at one doore, and Corineus at the other.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Art thou that&H62; Humber prince of fugitives,
That&H61; by&H4; thy treason slewest young Albanact ?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I am his son that&H61; slew young Albanact,
And if thou take not heed proud Phrigian,
I will send thy soul unto the Stigian lake,
There to&H9; complain of Humbers injuries.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: You triumph sir before the victory,
For&H3; Corineus is not so&H51; soon slain.
But cursed Scithians you shall rue the day
That&H3; ever you came into Albania.
So&H52; perish that&H61; they envy Brittaines wealth,
So&H52; let them die with endless infamy,
And he that&H61; seeks his sovereign's overthrow,
Would this my club might aggravate his woe.
sp.stage: Strikes them both downe with his club. Enter Humber.
sp.l: Where may I find some desert wilderness,
Where I may breath out curses as I would,
And scare the earth with my condemning voice,
Where every echoes repercussion
May help me to&H9; bewail mine overthrow,
And aid me in&H4; my sorrowful laments?
Where may I find some hollow uncouth rock,
Where I may damn, condemn and ban my fill,
The heavens, the hell, the earth, the air, the fire,
And utter curses to&H4; the concave sky,
Which&H61; may infect the airy regions,
And light upon&H4; the Brittain Locrines head?
You ugly sprites that&H61; in&H4; Cocitus mourn,
And gnash your teeth with dolorous laments,
Yea fearful dogs that&H61; in&H4; black Lathe howl,
And scare the ghosts with your wide open throats,
You ugly ghosts that&H61; flying from these dogs,
Do plunge yourselves in&H4; Puryflegiton,
Come all of you, and with your shrieking notes
Accompany the Brittaines conquering host.
Come fierce Erinnis horrible with snakes,
Come ugly Furies, armed with your whips,
You threefold judges of black Tartarus,
And all the army of you hellish fiends,
With new found torments rack proud Locrins bones
O gods, and stars, damned be the gods and stars
That&H61; did not drown me in&H4; fair Thetis plains.
Cursed be the sea that&H61; with outrageous waves
With surging billows did not rive my ships
Against the rocks of high Cerannia,
Or swallowed me into her&H2; watery gulf,
Would God We&Htp; had arrived upon&H4; the shore
Where Poliphlemus and the Cyclops dwell,
Or where the bloody Anthropomphagie
With greedy jaws devours the wandering wights,
But why comes Albanacts bloody ghost,
To&H9; bring a corsive to&H4; our&Htp; miseries?
Is it not enough to&H9; suffer shameful flight,
But We&Hrp; must be tormented now with ghosts,
With apparitions fearful to&H9; behold.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Revenge, revenge for&H4; blood.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: So&H3; naught will&H1; satisfy your wandering ghost
But dire revenge, nothing but Humbers fall,
Because he conquered you in&H4; Vlbany.
Now by&H4; my soul Humber would be condemned
To&H4; Tanals hunger or Ixions wheel,
Or to&H4; the vulture of Prometheus,
Rather than that&H3; this murther were undone.
When as I die i will drag thy cursed ghost
Through all the rivers of foul Erebus,
Through burning sulphur of the Limbo-lake
To&H9; allay the burning fury of that&H62; heat
That&H61; rageth in&H4; mine everlasting soul.

div2.head: The 4. Act. Scene 1.
div2.stage: Enter Ate as before. Then let their follow Omphale daughter to&H4; the king of Lydia, hauing a club in her&H2; hand, and a lions skinne on&H4; her&H2; back, Hercules following with a distaffe. Then let Omphale turn about, and taking off her&H2; pantofle, strike Hercules on&H4; the head, then let them depart. Ate remaining, saying;

l.foreign: Quem non Argolici mandata seuera Tyranni,
Non potuit Iuno vincere, vicit amor.

sp.l: Stout Hercules the mirror of the world,
Son to&H4; Almena and great Iupiter,
After so&H51; many conquests won in&H4; field,
After so&H51; many monsters quelled by&H4; force,
Yielded his valiant heart to&H4; Omphale,
A fearful woman void of manly strength,
She took the club, and ware the lions skin,
He took the wheel, and maidenly gan spin.
So&H3; martial Locrine cheered with victory,
Falleth in&H4; love with Humbers concubine,
And so&H52; forgetteth peerless Guendoline.
His uncle Corineus storms at this,
And forceth Locrine for&H4; his grace to&H9; sue,
Lo here the sum, the process doth ensue.

div2.head: The 2. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Locrine, Camber, Corineus, Assaracus, Thrasimachus, and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Thus from the fury of Bellonas broils,
With sound of drum and trumpets melody,
The Brittaine king returns triumphantly,
The Scithians slain with great occision,
Do equalise the grass in&H4; multitude,
And with their blood have stained the streaming brooks,
Offering their bodies and their dearest blood
As sacrifice to&H4; Albanactus ghost,
Now cursed Humber hast thou paid thy due,
For&H4; thy deceits and crafty treacheries,
For&H4; all thy guises, and damned stratagems,
With loss of life, and ever during shame.
Where are thy horses trapped with burnished gold,
Thy trampling coursers ruled with foaming bits?
Where are thy soldiers strong and numberless,
Thy valiant captains and thy noble peers?
Even as the country clowns with sharpest scythes
Do mow the withered grass from off the earth,
Or as the ploughman with his piercing share
Renteth the bowels of the fertile fields,
And rippeth up&H5; the roots with razors keen.
So&H3; Locrine with his mighty curtle-axe,
Hath cropped off the heads of all thy Hunnes,
So&H3; Locrines peers have daunted all thy peers,
And drove thine host unto confusion,
That&H3; thou mayst suffer penance for&H4; thy fault,
And die for&H4; murdering valiant Albanact.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: And thus, yea thus shall all the rest be served
That&H61; seek to&H9; enter Albion gainst our&Htp; wills.
If the brave nation of the Troglodites,
If all the coalblack Aethiopians,
If all the forces of the Amazons,
If all the hostess of the Barbarian lands,
Should dare to&H9; enter this our&Htp; little world,
Soon should they rue their overbold attempts,
That&H3; after us&Htp; our&Htp; progeny may say,
There lie the beasts that&H61; sought to&H9; usurp our&Htp; land.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Aye they are beasts that&H61; seek to&H9; usurp our&Htp; land,
And like&H4; to&H4; brutish beasts they shall be served.
For&H3; mighty love the supreme king of heaven,
That&H61; guides the concourse of the Meteors,
And rules the motion of the azure sky,
Fights always for&H4; the Brittaines safety.
But stay, methinks I hear some shrieking noise,
That&H61; draweth near to&H4; our&Htp; pavilion.

div2.stage: Enter the souldiers leading in Estrild.

sp.speaker: Estrild.
sp.l: What prince soever adorned with golden
Doth sway the regal sceptre in&H4; his hand:
And thinks no&H2; chance can ever throw him down,
Or that&H3; his state shall everlasting stand,
Let him behold poor Estrild in&H4; this plight,
The perfect platform of a troubled wight.
Once was I guarded with mavortial bands,
Compassed with princes of the noble blood,
Now am I fallen into my foemens hands,
And with my death must pacify their mood.
O life the harbour of calamities,
O death the haven of all miseries,
I could compare my sorrows to&H4; thy woe,
Thou wretched queen of wretched Pergamus,
But that&H3; thou viewdest thy enemies overthrow.
Nigh to&H4; the rock of high Caphareus,
Thou sawest their death, and then departedst thence,
I must abide the victors insolence.
The gods that&H61; pitied thy continual grief,
Transformed thy corps, and with thy corps thy care,
Poor Estrild lives despairing of relief,
For&H3; friends in&H4; trouble are but few and rare.
What said I few? Aye few or none at all,
For&H3; cruel death made havoc of them all.
Thrice happy they whose fortune was so&H51; good,
To&H9; end their lives, and with their lives their woes,
Thrice hapless I, whom fortune so&H51; withstood,
That&H3; cruelly she gave me to&H4; my foes.
O soldiers is there any misery,
To&H9; be compared to&H4; fortunes treachery.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Camber, this fame should be the Scithian queen.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So&H52; may We&Htp; judge by&H4; her&H2; lamenting words.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: So&H51; fair a dame mine eyes did never see,
With floods of woes she seems overwhelmed to&H9; be

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O Locrine hath she not a cause for&H3; to&H9; be sad?
Locrine at one side of the stage.
If she have cause to&H9; weep for&H4; Humbers death,
And shed salt tears for&H4; her&H2; overthrow,
Locrine may well bewail his proper grief,
Locrine may move his own peculiar woe,
He being conquered died a speedy death,
And felt not long his lamentable smart,
I being conqueror, live a lingering life,
And feel the force of Cupids sudden stroke.
I gave him cause to&H9; die a speedy death,
He left me cause to&H9; wish a speedy death.
O that&H62; sweet face painted with nature's dye,
Those roseall checks mixed with a snowy white,
That&H62; decent neck surpassing ivory,
Those comely breasts which&H61; Venus well might spite,
Are like&H5; to&H4; snares which&H61; wily fowlers wrought
Wherein my yielding heart is prisoner caught.
The golden tresses of her&H2; dainty hair
Which&H61; shine like&H4; rubies glittering with the sun,
Have so&H51; entrapped poor Locrines lovesick heart,
That&H3; from the same no&H2; way it can be won.
How true is that&H62; which&H61; oft I heard declared,
One dram of joy, must have a pound of care.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Hard is their fall who&H61; from a golden crown
Are cast into a sea of wretchedness.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Hard is their thrall who&H61; by&H4; Cupids frown
Are wrapped in&H4; waves of endless carefulness.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: O kingdom object to&H4; all miseries.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: O love, the extremest of all extremities.
Let him go into his chair.

sp.speaker: A sold.
sp.l: My Lord, in&H4; ransacking the Scithian tents
I found this Lady, and to&H9; manifest
That&H62; earnest zeal I bear unto your grace,
I here present her&H6; to&H4; your majesty.

sp.speaker: Another sold.
sp.l: He lies my Lord, I found the Lady first,
And here present her&H6; to&H4; your majesty.

sp.speaker: 1.sold.
sp.l: Presumptuous villain wilt thou take my prize?

sp.speaker: 2.sol.
sp.l: Nay rather thou deprivest me of my right.

sp.speaker: 1.sol.
sp.l: Resign thy title (caitiff) unto me,
Or with my sword i will pearce thy cowards loins.

sp.speaker: 2.sol.
sp.l: Soft words good sir, it is not enough to&H9; speak
A barking dog doth seldom strangers bite.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Unreverent villains, strive you in&H4; our&Hrp; sight?
Take them hence Jailer to&H4; the dungeon,
There let them lie and try their quarrel out.
But thou fair princess be no&H2; whit dismayed,
But rather joy that&H3; Locrine favours thee.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: How can he favour me that&H61; slew my spouse?

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: The chance of war (my love) took him from thee

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: But Locrine was the causer of his death.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: He was an enemy to&H4; Locrines state,
And slew my noble brother Albanact.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: But he was linked to&H4; me in&H4; marriage bond,
And would you have me love his slaughterer?

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Better to&H9; live, than not to&H9; live at all.

sp.speaker: Estrild.
sp.l: Better to&H9; die renowned for&H4; chastity,
Than live with shame and endless infamy.
What would the common sort report of me,
If I forget my love, and cleave to&H4; thee?

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Kings need not fear the vulgar sentences.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: But Ladies must regard their honest name.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Is it a shame to&H9; live in&H4; marriage bonds?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: No&H7;, but to&H9; be a strumpet to&H4; a king.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: If thou wilt yield to&H4; Locrines burning love,
Thou shalt be queen of fair Albania.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: But Gendoline will&H1; undermine my state.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Upon&H4; mine honour thou shalt have no&H2; harm.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Then lo brave Locrine, Estrild yields to&H4; thee,
And by&H4; the gods whom thou dost invocate,
By&H4; the dead ghost of thy deceased sire,
By&H4; thy right hand and by&H4; thy burning love,
Take pity on&H4; poor Estrilds wretched thrall.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Hath Locrine then forgot his Guendoline,
That&H3; thus he courts the Scithians paramour?
What are the words of Brute so&H51; soon forgot?
Are my deserts so&H51; quickly out of mind?
Have I been faithful to&H4; thy fire now dead,
Have I protected thee from Humbers hands,
And dost thou quite me with ingratitude?
Is this the guerdon for&H4; my grievous wounds,
Is this the honour for&H4; my labors past?
Now by&H4; my sword, Locrine I swear to&H4; thee,
This injury of thine shall be repaid.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Uncle, scorn you your royal sovereign,
As if We&Hrp; stood for&H4; ciphers in&H4; the court?
Upbraid you me with those your benefits?
Why it was a subject's duty so&H52; to&H9; do.
What you have done for&H4; our&Hrp; deceased sire,
We&Hrp; know, and all know you have your reward.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Avaunt proud princox, bravest thou me withal,
Assure thy self though thou be Emperor
Thou never shalt carry this unpunished.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pardon my brother noble Corineus,
Pardon this once and it shall be amended.

sp.speaker: Affar.
sp.l: Cousin remember Brutus latest words,
How he desired you to&H9; cherish them,
Let not this fault so&H51; much incense your mind.
Which&H61; is not yet passed all remedy.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Then Locrine, lo I reconcile myself,
But as thou lovest thy life, so&H52; love thy wife:
But if thou violate those promises,
Blood and revenge shall light upon&H4; thy head.
Come let us&Htp; back to&H4; stately Troinouant,
Where all these matters shall be settled.
Millions of devils wait upon&H4; thy soul.
Legion of spirits vex thy impious ghost.
Ten thousand torments rack thy cursed bones.
Let everything that&H61; hath the use of breath,
Be instruments and workers of thy death.

div2.head: The 3. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Humber alone, his haire hanging ouer his shoulders, his armes all bloodie, and a dart in&H4; one hand.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: What basilisk was hatched in&H4; this place,
Where everything consumed is to&H4; naught?
What fearful Fury haunts these cursed groves
Where not a root is left for&H4; Humbers meat?
Hath fell Alecto with envenomed blasts,
Breathed forth poison in&H4; these tender plains?
Hath triple Cerberus with contagious foam,
Sowed Aconitum mongst these withered herbs?
Hath dreadful Fames with her&H2; charming rods
Brought barrenness on&H4; every fruitful tree?
What not a root, no&H2; fruit, no&H2; beast, no&H2; bird,
To&H9; nourish Humber in&H4; this wilderness?
What would you more you fiends of Erebus,
My very entrails burn for&H4; want of drink,
My bowels cry, Humber give us&Htp; some meat,
But wretched Humber can give you no&H2; meat,
These foul accursed groves afford no&H2; meat.
This fruitless soil, this ground brings forth no&H2; meat
The gods, hard hearted gods, yield me no&H2; meat.
Then how can Humber give you any meat?

div2.stage: Enter Strumbo with a pitchforke, and a scotch-cap, saying:

sp.p: How do you masters, how do you? how have you scaped hanging this long time? yfaith I have scaped many a scouring this year, but I thank God I have past them all with a good couragio, couragio, and my wife and I are in&H4; great love and charity now, I thank my manhood and my strength, for&H3; I will&H1; tell you masters, upon&H4; a certain day at night I came home, to&H9; say the very truth, with my stomach full of wine, and ran up&H5; into the chamber where my wife soberly sate rocking my little baby, leaning her&H2; back against the bed, singing lullaby. Now when she saw me come with my nose foremost, thinking that&H3; I been drunk, as I was indeed, snatched up&H5; a faggot stick in&H4; her&H2; hand, and came furiously marching towards me with a big face, as though she would have eaten me at a bit; thundering out these words unto me. Thou drunken knave where hast thou been so&H51; long? I shall teach thee how to&H9; benight me another time; and so&H3; she began to&H9; play knaues trumps. Now although I trembled fearing she would set her&H2; ten commandments in&H4; my face, ran within her&H6;, and taking her&H6; lustily by&H4; the middle, I carried her&H6; valiantly to&H4; the bed, and flinging her&H6; upon&H4; it, flung myself upon&H4; her&H6;, and there I delighted her&H6; so&H51; with the sport I made, that&H3; ever after she wold call me sweet husband, and so&H3; banished brawling forever: and to&H9; see the good will&H0; of the wench, she bought with her&H2; portion a yard of land, and by&H4; that&H62; I am now become one of the richest men in&H4; our&Htp; parish. Well masters what is o'clock, it is now breakfast time, you shall see what meat I have here for&H4; my breakfast.
sp.l: Let him sit down and pull out
his victuals.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.l: Was ever land so&H51; fruitless as this land?
Was ever grove so&H51; graceless as this grove?
Was ever soil so&H51; barren as this soil?
O no&H7;: the land where hungry Fames dwelt,
May no&H2; wise equalise this cursed land,
No&H7; even the climate of the torrid zone
Brings forth more fruit than this accursed grove.
Never came sweet Ceres, never came Venus here,
Triptolemus the god of husbandmen,
Never sowed his seed in&H4; this foul wilderness.
The hunger-bitten dogs of Acheron,
Chased from the ninefold Puriflegiton,
Have set their footsteps in&H4; this damned ground.
The iron hearted Furies armed with snakes,
Scattered huge Hidras over all the plains,
which&H61; have consumed the grass, the herbs, the trees
which&H61; have drunk up&H5; the flowing water springs.

div2.stage: Strumbo hearing his voice shall start up&H5; and put meat in his pocket, seeking to hide himselfe.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Thou great commander of the starry sky,
That&H61; guidest the life of every mortal wight
From the enclosures of the fleeting clouds,
Rain down some food, or else I faint and die.
Pour down some drink, or else I faint and die.
O Iupiter hast thou sent Mercury
In&H4; clownish shape to&H9; minister some food?
Some meat, some meat, some meat.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.l: O alas sir, ye are deceived, I am not Mercury, I am Strumbo.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Give me some meat villain, give me some meat,
Or gainst this rock, I will dash thy cursed brains,
And rent thy bowels with my bloody hands.
Give me some meat villain, give me some meat.

sp.speaker: Strum.
sp.p: By&H4; the faith of my body good fellow, I had rather give an whole ox than that&H3; thou shouldst serve me in&H4; that&H62; sort. Dash out my brains? O horrible, terrible. I think I have a quarry of stones in&H4; my pocket.

div2.stage: Let him make as though hee would giue him some, and as he putteth out his hand, enter the ghoast of Albanact, and strike him on the hand, and so Strumbo runnes out, Humber following him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alba. ghost.
sp.l: Lo here the gift of fell ambition,
Of usurpation and of treachery.
Lo here the harms that&H61; wait upon&H4; all those
That&H61; do intrude themselves in&H4; others lands,
Which&H61; are not under their dominion.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Seven years hath aged Corineus lived
To&H4; Locrines grief, and fair Estrilds woe,
And seven years more he hopeth yet to&H9; live,
O supreme Jove, annihilate this thought.
Should he enjoy the aires fruition?
Should he enjoy the benefit of life?
Should he contemplate the radiant son,
That&H61; makes my life equal to&H4; dreadful death?
Venus convey this monster fro the earth,
That&H61; disobeyeth thus thy sacred hests.
Cupid convey this monster to&H4; dark hell,
That&H61; disannuls thy mothers sugared laws.
Mars with thy target all beset with flames,
With murthering blade bereave him of his life,
That&H61; hindereth Locrine in&H4; his sweetest joys.
And yet for&H4; all his diligent aspect,
His wrathful eyes piercing like&H4; Linces' eyes,
Well have I overmatched his subtlety.
Nigh Deucolitum by&H4; the pleasant Lee,
where brackish Thamis slides with silver streams,
Making a breach into the grassy downs,
A curious arch of costly marble fraught,
Hath Locrine framed underneath the ground,
The walls whereof, garnish with diamonds,
With ophirs, rubies, glistering emeralds,
And interlaced with sun-bright carbuncles,
Lighten the room with artificial day,
And from the Lee with water-flowing pipes
The moisture is derived into this arch
Where I have placed fair Estrild secretly,
Thither eftsoons accompanied with my page,
I covertly visit my heart's desire,
Without suspicion of the meanest eye,
For&H3; love aboundeth still with policy:
And thither still means Locrine to&H9; repair,
Till Atropos cut off mine uncle's life.

div2.head: The 5. Scene.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Long have I lived in&H4; this desert cave,
With eating haws and miserable roots,
Devouring leaves and beastly excrements.
Caves were my beds, and stones my pillow bears,
Fear was my sleep, and horror was my dream,
For&H3; still methought at every boisterous blast
Now Locrine comes, now Humber thou must die:
So&H3; that&H3; for&H4; fear and hunger, Humbers mind
Can never rest, but always trembling stands.
O what Danubius now may quench my thirst?
What Euphrates, what light-foot Euripus,
May now allay the fury of that&H62; heat,
Which&H61; raging in&H4; my entrails eats me up&H5;?
You ghastly devils of the ninefold Sticks,
You damned ghosts of joyless Acheron,
You mournful souls, vexed in&H4; Abissus vaults,
You coalblack devils of Auerns pond,
Come with your flesh hooks, rent my famished arms,
These arms that&H61; have sustained their master's life,
Come with your razors, rip my bowels up&H5;,
With your sharp fireforks crack my starved bones,
