Use me as you will&H1;, so&H3; Humber may not live.
Accursed gods that&H61; rule the starry poles,
Accursed Jove king of the cursed gods,
Cast down your lightning on&H4; poor Humbers head,
That&H3; I may leave this deathlike life of mine,
What hear you not, and shall not Humber die?
Nay I will&H1; die though all the gods say nay.
And gentle Aby take my troubled corps,
Take it and keep it from all moral eyes,
That&H3; none may say when I have lost my breath,
The very floods conspired gainst Humbers death.

div2.stage: Fling himselfe into the riuer Enter the ghoast of Albanact

l.foreign: Encaedem sequitur, caedes in caede quieso.

sp.l: Humber is dead, joy heavens, leap earth, dance trees
Now mayst thou reach thy apples Tantalus,
And with them feed thy hunger-bitten limbs.
Now Sisiphus leave tumbling of thy rock,
And rest thy restless bones upon&H4; the same.
Unbind Ixion cruel Rhadamanth,
And lay proud Humber on&H4; the whirling wheel.
Back will&H1; I post to&H4; hell mouth Taenarus
And pass Cocitus, to&H4; the Elysian fields,
And tell my father Brutus of these news.

div2.head: The 5. Act. Scene 1.
div2.stage: Enter Ate as before. Iason leading Creons daughter. Medea following, hath a garland in her hand, and putting it on Creons daughters head, setteth it on fire, and then killing Iason and her, departeth.

sp.speaker: Ate

l.foreign: Laesae furtino quam cor mlieris amore.

sp.l: Medea seeing Iason leave her&H2; love,
And choose the daughter of the Thebane king,
Went to&H4; her&H2; devilish charms to&H9; work revenge,
And raising up&H5; the triple Hecate,
With all the rout of the condemned fiends,
Framed a garland by&H4; her&H2; magic skill,
With which&H61; she wrought Iason and Creons ill.
So&H3; Guendoline seeing herself misused,
And Humbers paramour possess her&H2; place,
Flies to&H4; the dukedom of Cornubia,
And with her&H2; brother stout Thrasimachus,
Gathering a power of Cornish soldiers,
Gives battle to&H4; her&H2; husband and his host,
Nigh to&H4; the river of great Mertia,
The chances of this dismal massacre,
That&H62; which&H61; ensueth shortly will&H1; unfold.

div2.head: The 2. Scene.

sp.speaker: Affa.
sp.l: But tell me cousin, died by&H4; brother so&H52;?
Now who&H62; is left to&H4; helpless Albion,
That&H61; as a pillar might uphold our&Hrp; state,
That&H61; might strike terror to&H4; our&Hrp; daring foes?
Now who&H62; is left to&H4; hapless Brittanie,
That&H61; might defend her&H6; from the barbarous hands
Of those that&H61; still desire her&H2; ruinous fall,
And seek to&H9; work her&H2; downfall and decay?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Aye uncle death is our&Htp; common enemy,
And none but death can match our&Htp; matchless power
Witness the fall of Albioneus crew,
Witness the fall of Humber and his Hunnes,
And this foul death hath now increased our&Htp; woe,
By&H4; taking Corineus from this life,
And in&H4; his room leaving us&Htp; worlds of care.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: But none may more bewail his mournful hearse,
Than I that&H61; am the issue of his loins,
Now foul befall that&H62; cursed Humbers throat,
That&H61; was the causer of his lingering wound.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Tears cannot raise him from the dead again,
But where is my Lady mistress Guendoline?

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: In&H4; Cornwall Locrine is my sister now,
Providing for&H4; my fathers funeral.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And let her&H6; there provide her&H2; mourning weeds
And mourn forever her&H2; own widowhood.
Never shall she come within our&Hrp; palace gate,
To&H9; countercheck brave Locrine in&H4; his love.
Go boy to&H4; Deucolitum, down the Lee,
Unto the arch where lovely Estrild lies,
Bring her&H6; and Sabren strait unto the court,
She shall be queen in&H4; Guendolinas room.
Let others wail for&H4; Corineus death,
I mean not so&H52; to&H9; macerate my mind,
For&H4; him that&H61; bard me from my hearts desire.

sp.speaker: Thra
sp.l: Hath Locrine then forsook his Guendoline?
Is Corineus death so&H51; soon forgot?
If there be gods in&H4; heaven, as sure there be,
If there be fiends in&H4; hell, as needs there must,
They will&H1; revenge this thy notorious wrong,
And pour their plagues upon&H4; thy cursed head.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: What pratest thou peasant to&H4; thy sovereign
Or art thou strucken in&H4; some ecstasy?
Dost thou not tremble at our&Hrp; royal looks?
Dost thou not quake when mighty Locrine frowns?
Thou beardless boy, wert not that&H3; Locrine scorns
To&H9; vex his mind with such a heartless child,
With the sharpe point of this my battle-axe,
I would send thy soul to&H4; Puriflegiton.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Though I be young and of a tender age,
Yet will&H1; I cope with Locrine when he dares.
My noble father with his conquering sword,
Slew the two giants kings of Aquitaine.
Thrasimachus is not so&H51; degenerate
That&H3; he should fear and tremble at the looks
Or taunting words of a venerian squire.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Menacest thou thy royal sovereign,
Uncivil, not beseeming such as you.
Injurious traitor (for&H3; he is no&H2; less
That&H61; at defiance standeth with his king)
Leave these thy taunts, leave these thy bragging words,
Unless thou mean to&H9; leave thy wretched life.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: If princes stain their glorious dignity
With ugly spots of monstrous infamy,
They lose their former estimation,
And throw themselves into a hell of hate.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Wilt thou abuse my gentle patience,
As though thou didst our&Hrp; high displeasure scorn?
Proud boy, that&H3; thou mayst know thy prince is moved,
Yea greatly moved at this thy swelling pride,
We&Hrp; banish thee forever from our&Hrp; court.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Then losel Locrine, look unto thyself,
Thrasimachus will&H1; venge this injury.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Farewell proud boy, and learn to&H9; use thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Affa.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, you should have called to&H4; mind
The latest words that&H61; Brutus spake to&H4; you,
How he desired you by&H4; the obedience
That&H61; children ought to&H9; bear unto their sire
To&H9; love and favour Lady Guendoline,
Consider this, that&H3; if the injury
Do move her&H2; mind, as certainly it will&H1;,
War and dissension follows speedily.
What though her&H2; power be not so&H51; great as yours,
Have you not seen a mighty elephant
Slain by&H4; the biting of a lily mouse?
Even so&H52; the chance of war inconstant is.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Peace uncle peace, and cease to&H9; talk hereof,
For&H3; he that&H61; seeks by&H4; whispering this or that&H62;,
To&H9; trouble Locrine in&H4; his sweetest life,
Let him persuade himself to&H9; die the death.

div2.stage: Enter the Page, with Estrild and Sabren.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: O say me Page, tell me where is the king,
Wherefore doth he send for&H4; me to&H4; the court,
Is it to&H9; die, is it to&H9; end my life,
Say me sweet boy, tell me and do not fain?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No&H7; trust me madam, if you will&H1; credit the little honesty that&H61; is yet let me, there is no&H2; such danger as you fear, but prepare yourself, yonder is the king.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Then Estrild lift thy dazzled spirits up&H5;,
And bless that&H62; blessed time, that&H62; day, that&H62; hour,
That&H61; warlike Locrine first did favour thee.
Peace to&H4; the king of Brittany my love,
Peace to&H4; all those that&H61; love and favour him.
Doth Estrild fall with such submission
Before her&H2; servant king of Albion?
Arise fair Lady, leave this lowly cheer,
Lift up&H5; those looks that&H61; cherish Locrines heart,
That&H3; I may freely view that&H62; roseall face,
Which&H61; so&H51; entangled hath my lovesick breast,
Now to&H4; the court where we&Htp; will&H1; court it out,
And pass the night and day in&H4; Venus sports.
Frolic brave peers, be joyful with your king.

div2.head: The 3.Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Guendoline, Thrasimachus, Madan, and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: You gentle winds that&H61; with your modest blasts,
Pass through the circuit of the heavenly vault,
Enter the clouds unto the throne of Jove,
And bear my prayers to&H4; his all hearing ears,
For&H3; Locrine hath forsaken Guendoline,
And learn to&H9; love proud Humbers concubine.
You happy sprites that&H61; in&H4; the concave sky
With pleasant joy, enjoy your sweetest love,
Shed forth those tears with me, which&H61; then you shed
When first you wooed your ladies to&H4; your wills,
Those tears are fittest for&H4; my woeful case,
Since Locrine shuns my nothing pleasant face.
Blush heavens, blush sun, and hide thy shining beams,
Shadow thy radiant locks in&H4; gloomy clouds,
Deny thy cheerful light unto the world,
Where nothing reigns but falsehood and deceit.
What said I, falsehood? Aye that&H62; filthy crime,
For&H3; Locrine hath forsaken Guendoline.
Behold the heavens do wail for&H4; Guendoline.
The shining sun doth blush for&H4; Guendoline.
The liquid air doth weep for&H4; Guendoline.
The very ground doth groan for&H4; Guendoline.
Aye they are milder than the Brittaine king,
For&H3; he rejecteth luckless Guendoline.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Sister, complaints are bootless in&H4; this cause,
This open wrong must have an open plague:
This plague must be repaid with grievous war,
This war must finish with Locrinus death,
His death will&H1; soon extinguish our&Htp; complaints.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: O no&H7;, his death will&H1; more augment my woes,
He was my husband brave Thrasimachus,
More dear to&H4; me than the apple of mine eye,
Nor can I find in&H4; heart to&H9; work his scathe.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Madam if not your proper injuries,
Nor my exile, can move you to&H9; revenge,
Think on&H4; our&Hrp; father Corineus words,
His words to&H4; us&Htp; stands always for&H4; a law,
Should Locrine live that&H61; caused my fathers death?
Should Locrine live that&H61; now divorced you?
The heavens, the earth, the air, the fire reclaims,
And then why should all we&Htp; deny the same?

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: Then henceforth farewell womanish complaints,
All childish pity henceforth then farewell:
But cursed Locrine look unto thyself,
For&H3; Nemesis the mistress of revenge,
Sits armed at all points on&H4; our&Htp; dismal blades,
And cursed Estrild that&H61; inflamed his heart,
Shall if I live, die a reproachful death.

sp.speaker: Madan.
sp.l: Mother, though nature makes me to&H9; lament,
My luckless fathers froward lechery,
Yet for&H3; he wrongs my Lady mother thus,
Aye if I could, myself would work his death.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: See madam see, the desire of revenge
Is in&H4; the children of a tender age.
Forward brave soldiers into Mertia,
Where we&Htp; shall brave the coward to&H4; his face.

div2.head: The 4. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter Locrine, Estrild, Habren, Assarachus, and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Tell me Assarachus, are the Cornish chuffs
In&H4; such great number come to&H4; Mertia,
And have they pitched there their petty host,
So&H51; close unto our&Hrp; royal mansion.

sp.speaker: Affa.
sp.l: They are my Lord, and mean incontinent
To&H9; bid defiance to&H4; your majesty.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: It makes me laugh, to&H9; think that&H3; Guendoline
Should have the heart to&H9; come in&H4; arms gainst me.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, the horse will&H1; run amain
When as the spur doth gall him to&H4; the bone,
Jealousy Locrine hath a wicked sting.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.l: Sayst thou so&H52; Estrild, beauties paragon?
Well We&Hrp; will&H1; try her&H2; choler to&H4; the proof,
And make her&H6; know Locrine can brooke no&H2; braves.
March on&H5; Assarachus, thou must lead the way,
And bring us&Htp; to&H4; their proud pavilion.

div2.head: The 5. Scene.
div2.stage: Enter the ghost of Corineus, with thunder and lightening.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Behold the circuit of the azure sky,
Throws forth sad throbs, and grievous suspirs,
Prejudicating Locrines overthrow,
The fire casteth forth sharpe darts of flames,
The great foundation of the triple world,
Trembleth and quaketh with a mighty noise,
Presaging bloody massacres at hand.
The wandering birds that&H61; flutter in&H4; the dark,
When hellish night in&H4; cloudy chariot seared,
Casteth her&H2; mists on&H4; shady Tellus face,
With sable mantels covering all the earth,
Now flies abroad amid the cheerful day,
Foretelling some unwonted misery.
The snarling curs of darkened Tartarus,
Sent from Auernus ponds by&H4; Radamanth,
With howling ditties pester every wood,
The watery ladies and the light foot fawns,
And all the rabble of the woody Nymphs,
All trembling hide themselves in&H4; shady groves,
And shroud themselves in&H4; hideous hollow pits.
The boisterous Boreas thundereth forth revenge.
The stony rocks cry out on&H4; sharpe revenge.
The thorny bush pronounceth dire revenge.
Now Corineus stay and see revenge,
And feed thy soul with Locrines overthrow.
Behold they come, the trumpets call them forth.
The roaring drums summon the soldiers.
Lo where their army glistereth on&H4; the plains,
Throw forth thy lightning mighty Iupiter,
And pour thy plagues on&H4; cursed Locrines head.

div2.stage: Enter Locrine, Estrild, Assaracus, Habren and their soldiers at one doore, Thrasimachus, Guendolin, Madan and their followers at an other.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: What is the tiger started from his cave?
Is Guendoline come from Cornubia,
That&H3; thus she braved Locrine to&H4; the teeth?
And hast thou found thine armour pretty boy,
Accompanied with these thy straggling mates?
Believe me but this enterprise was bold,
And well deserveth commendation.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: Aye Locrine, traitorous Locrine we&Htp; are come,
With full pretence to&H9; seek thine overthrow,
What have I done that&H3; thou shouldst scorn me thus?
What have I said that&H3; thou shouldst me reject?
Have I been disobedient to&H4; thy words?
Have I bewrayed thy Arcane secrecy?
Have I dishonoured thy marriage bed
With filthy crimes, or with lascivious lusts?
Nay it is thou that&H61; hast dishonoured it,
Thy filthy mind overcome with filthy lusts,
Yieldeth unto affections filthy darts.
Unkind, thou wrongest thy first and truest feer,
Unkind, thou wrongest thy best and dearest friend
Unkind, thou scornest all skilful Brutus laws,
Forgetting father, uncle, and thyself.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Believe me Locrine but the girl is wise,
And well would seem to&H9; make a vestal Nun,
How finely frames she her&H2; oration.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Locrin we&Htp; came not here to&H9; fight with words
Words that&H61; can never win the victory,
But for&H3; you are so&H51; merry in&H4; your rumps,
Unsheathe your swords, and try it out by&H4; force,
That&H3; we&Htp; may see who&H61; hath the better hand.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: Thinkst thou to&H9; dare me bold Thrasimachus?
Thinkst thou to&H9; fear me with thy taunting braves,
Or do we&Hrp; seem too weak to&H9; cope with thee?
Soon shall I show thee my fine cutting blade,
And with my sword the messenger of death,
Seal thee an acquittance for&H4; thy bold attempts.

div2.stage: Sound the alarme. Enter Locrine, Assaracus, and souldier at one doore, Guendoline, Thrsimachus, at an other, Locrine and his followers driuen back. Then let Locrine and Estrild enter again in&H4; a maze.

sp.speaker: Loc.
sp.l: O fair Estrilda, we&Hrp; have lost the field,
Thrasimachus hath won the victory,
And we&Hrp; are left to&H9; be a laughing stock,
Scoffed at by&H4; those that&H61; are our&Hrp; enemies,
Ten thousand soldiers armed with sword and shield,
Prevail against an hundreth thousand men,
Thrasimachus incensed with fuming ire,
Rageth amongst the faint heart soldiers
Like&H4; to&H4; grim Mars, when covered with his targe
He fought with Diomedes in&H4; the field,
Close by&H4; the banks of silver Simois,
O lovely Estrild now the chase begins,
Never shall we&Htp; see the stately Traynouant
Mounted on&H4; the coursers garnished all with pearl
Never shall we&Htp; view the fair Concordia,
Unless as captives we&Htp; be thither brought.
Shall Locrine then be taken prisoner,
By&H4; such a youngling as Thrasimachus?
Shall Guendolina captivate my love?
Never shall mine eyes behold that&H62; dismal hour,
Never will&H1; I view that&H62; ruthful spectacle,
For&H3; with my sword this sharpe curtal axe,
I will cut in&H4; sunder my accursed heart.
But O you judges of the nine old Stix,
Which&H61; with incessant torments rack the ghosts
Within the bottomless Abissus pits,
You gods commanders of the heavenly spheres,
Whole will&H0; and law's irrevocable stands,
Forgive, forgive, this soul accursed sin,
Forget O gods this foul condemned fault:
And now my sword that&H61; in&H4; so&H51; many fights
Hast saved the life of Brutus and his son,
End now his life that&H61; wisheth still for&H4; death,
Work now his death that&H61; wisheth still for&H4; death,
Work now his death that&H61; hateth still his life.
Farewell fair Estrild, beauties paragon,
Framed in&H4; the front of forlorn miseries,
Never shall mine eyes behold thy sunshine eyes,
But when we&Htp; meet in&H4; the Elysian fields,
Thither I go before with hastened pace.
Farewell vain world, and thy enticing snares.
Farewell soul sin, and thy enticing pleasures.
And welcome death the end of mortal smart,
Welcome to&H4; Locrines overburthened heart.

div2.stage: Thrust himselfe through with his sword.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Break heart with sobs and grievous suspirs,
Stream forth you tears from forth my watery eyes,
Help me to&H9; mourn for&H4; warlike Locrines death,
Pour down your tears you watery regions,
For&H3; mighty Locrine is bereft of life.
O fickle fortune, O unstable world,
What else are all things that&H61; this globe contains,
But a confused chaos of mishaps?
Wherein as in&H4; a glass we&Htp; plainly see,
That&H3; all our&Htp; life is but as a Tragedy.
Since mighty kings are subject to&H4; mishap
Aye mighty kings are subject to&H4; mishap,
Since martial Locrine is bereft of life,
Shall Estrild live then after Locrines death?
Shall love of life bar her&H6; from Locrines sword?
O no&H7;, this sword that&H61; hath bereft his life,
Shall now deprive me of my fleeting soul:
Strengthen these hands O mighty Iupiter,
That&H3; I may end my woeful misery.
Locrine I come, Locrine I follow thee.

div2.stage: Kill her selfe. Sound the alarme. Enter Sabren.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: What doleful sight, what ruthful spectacle
Hath fortune offered to&H4; my hapless heart?
My father slain with such a fatal sword,
My mother murthered by&H4; a mortal wound?
What Thracian dog, what barbarous Mirmidon,
Would not relent at such a ruthful case?
What fierce Achilles, what hard stony flint,
Would not bemoan this mournful Tragedy?
Locrine the map of magnanimity,
Lies slaughtered in&H4; this foul accursed cave,
Estrild the perfect pattern of renown,
Nature's sole wonder, in&H4; whose beauteous breasts
All heavenly grace and vertue was enshrined,
Both massacred are dead within this cave,
And with them dies fair Pallas and sweet love.
Here lies a sword, and Sabren hath a heart,
This blessed sword shall cut my cursed heart,
And bring my soul unto my parents ghosts,
That&H3; they that&H61; live and view our&Htp; Tragedy,
May mourn our&Htp; case with mournful plaudities.
Let her&H6; offer to&H9; kill herself.
Ay me, my virgins hands are too too weak,
To&H9; penetrate the bulwark of my breast,
My fingers used to&H9; tune the amorous lute,
Are not of force to&H9; hold this steely glaive,
So&H3; I am left to&H9; wail my parents death,
Not able for&H3; to&H9; work my proper death.
Ah Locrine honoured for&H4; thy nobleness.
Ah Estrild, famous for&H4; thy constancy.
Ill may they fare that&H61; wrought your mortal ends.

div2.stage: Enter Guendoline, Thrasimachus, Madan, and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Guen
sp.l: Search soldiers search, find Locrin and his love,
Find the proud strumpet Humbers concubine,
That&H3; I may change those her&H2; so&H51; pleasing looks,
To&H4; pale and ignominious aspect.
Find me the issue of their cursed love,
Find me young Sabren, Locrines only joy,
That&H3; I may glut my mind with lukewarm blood,
Swiftly distilling from the bastards breast,
My fathers ghost still haunts me for&H4; revenge,
Crying, revenge my over-hastened death,
My brothers exile, and mine own divorce,
Banish remorse clean from my brazen heart,
All mercy from mine adaminitive breasts.

sp.speaker: Thra.
sp.l: Nor doth thy husband lovely Guendoline,
That&H61; wonted was to&H9; guide our&Htp; starless steps,
Enjoy this light; see where he murdered lies:
By&H4; luckless lot and froward frowning fate,
And by&H4; him lies his lovely paramour
Fair Estrild geared with a dismal sword,
And as it seems, both murdered by&H4; themselves,
Clasping each other in&H4; their feebled arms,
With loving zeal, as if for&H4; company
Their uncontented corpse were yet content
To&H9; pass soul Stix in&H4; Charans ferry-boat.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: And hath proud Estrild then prevented me
Hath she escaped Guendalins wrath,
Violently by&H4; cutting off her&H2; life?
Would God she had the monstrous Hidras lives,
That&H3; every hour she might have died a death
Worse than the swing of old Ixions wheel,
And every hour revive to&H9; die again,
As Titius bound to&H4; houses Caucas,
Doth feed the substance of his own mishap,
And every day for&H4; want of food doth die,
And every night doth live again to&H4; die.
But stay, methinks I hear some fainting voice,
Mournfully weeping for&H4; their luckless death.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: You mountain nymphs which&H61; in&H4; these deserts reign,
Cease off your hasty chase of savage beasts,
Prepare to&H9; see a heart oppressed with care,
Address your ears to&H9; hear a mournful style,
No&H2; human strength, no&H2; work can work my weal,
Care in&H4; my heart so&H51; tyrant-like doth deal.
You Driades and light-foot Satiri,
You gracious Fairies which&H61; at evening tide,
Your closets leave with heavenly beauty stored,
And on&H4; your shoulders spread your golden locks,
You savage bears in&H4; caves and darkened dens,
Come wail with me, the martial Locrines death.
Come mourn with me, for&H4; beauteous Estrilds death.
Ah loving parents little do you know,
what sorrow Sabren suffers for&H4; your thrall.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: But may this be, and is it possible,
Lives Sabren yet to&H9; expiate my wrath?
Fortune I thank thee for&H4; this courtesy,
And let me never see one prosperous hour,
If Sabren die not a reproachful death.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Hard hearted death, that&H61; when the wretched call,
Art furthest off, and seldom hear it at all.
But in&H4; the midst of fortunes good success,
Uncalled comes, and shears our&Htp; life in&H4; twain:
When will&H1; that&H62; hour, that&H62; blessed hour draw nigh,
When poor distressed Sabren may be gone.
Sweet Atropos cut off my fatal thread,
What art thou death, shall not poor Sabren die?

div2.stage: Guendoline taking her by&H4; the chin shall say thus.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: Yes damsel yes, Sabren shall surely die,
Though all the world should seek to&H9; save her&H2; life,
And not a common death shall Sabren die,
But after strange and grievous punishments
Shortly inflicted upon&H4; thy bastards head,
Thou shalt be cast into the cursed streams,
And feed the fishes with thy tender flesh.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: And think thou then thou cruel homicide,
That&H3; these thy deeds shall be unpunished?
No&H7; traitor no&H7;, the gods will&H0; venge these wrongs,
The fiends of hell will&H1; mark these injuries.
Never shall these blood-sucking masty curs,
Bring wretched Sabren to&H4; her&H2; latest home.
For&H3; I myself inspire of thee and thine,
Mean to&H9; abridge my former destinies,
And that&H62; which&H61; Locrines sword could not perform,
This pleasant stream shall present bring to&H9; pass.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.l: One mischief follows another's neck,
Who&H62; would have thought so&H51; young a maid as she
With such a courage wold have sought her&H2; death.
And for&H3; because his River was the place
Where little Sabren resolutely died,
Sabren forever shall this same be called.
And as for&H4; Locrine our&Hrp; deceased spouse,
Because he was the son of mighty Brute
To&H4; whom we&Htp; owe our&Htp; country, lives and goods,
He shall be buried in&H4; a stately tomb,
Close by&H4; his aged father Brutus bones,
With such great pomp and great solemnity
As well beseems so&H51; brave a prince as be
Let Estrild lie without the shallow
Without the honour due unto the dead
Because she was the author of this war.
Retire brave followers unto Troynonment
Where we&Htp; will&H1; celebrate these exequies
And place young Locrin his fathers tomb.

sp.speaker: Ate.
sp.l: Lo here the end of lawless treachery,
Of usurpation and ambitious pride,
And they that&H61; for&H4; their private amours dare
Turmoil our&Htp; land, and their broils abroach,
Let them be warned by&H4; these premises,
And as a woman was the only cause
That&H3; civil discord was then stirred up&H5;,
So&H3; let us&Htp; pray for&H4; that&H62; renowned maid,
That&H61; eight and thirty years the sceptre swayed,
In&H4; quiet peace and sweet felicity,
And every wight that&H61; seeks her&H2; graces smart,
wold that&H3; this sword were pierced in&H4; his heart.
